awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  TIDE: Legacy effects of long-term nutrient enrichment on recovery of saltmarsh ecosystems
awd_abstract_narration:
Coastal nutrient enrichment has resulted in saltmarshes being one of the most endangered ecosystems in the world. This over enrichment has compromised the ability of saltmarshes to provide key ecosystem services such as buffering coastal cities from storms, providing habitat for fish and shellfish, and mitigating climate impacts by storing carbon. The U.S. is investing millions of dollars to reduce nitrogen to coastal regions and embarking on large-scale saltmarsh restoration costing millions to billions of dollars to restore lost ecosystem services. Currently, it is unknown how quickly or if ecosystem services will return after nutrient inputs are cut. This research will provide insight into nitrogen pollution as a cause of marsh loss and the potential for ecosystem recovery with management strategies. There are several education efforts associated with this project that will train students. The project enhances education by developing high school curriculum on "Research and Resiliency: Investigating the Local Effects of Global Changes" in collaboration with the Massachusetts Audubon Society. A program for mid-career journalists about environmental science will also be developed. This project will facilitate sustainability and provide a science-based foundation for state and federal nutrient standards. 

This project will address how the effects of historical nutrient over enrichment influences the ability of marshes to recover their ability to provide ecosystem services. The project will use a combination of whole-ecosystem experimental manipulations, field measurements of key species, assays of genetic change, nutrient and carbon cycle processes, and food-web structure in six experimental sites to determine recovery trajectories. Researchers will measure changes in the decomposer community genetic diversity and activity by sequence amplicons of functional genes responsible for encoding key enzymes in the nitrogen cycling processes. The project will measure plant traits and genotypic diversity. The recovery of carbon and nitrogen cycling will be determined from marsh geomorphology, habitat-specific denitrification rates, nitrogen exchange with the open bay, and decomposition. Measuring the species diversity, abundance and productivity and stable isotope of invertebrates and fish will assess food web recovery.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The TIDE experiment has transformed our understanding of how nutrient enrichment impacts coastal ecosystems. Unlike earlier, small-scale studies, the TIDE Project stands out as the only long-term, large-scale (6 hectares per treatment) coastal wetland fertilization experiment in the world. By examining nutrient enrichment at the ecosystem level, it has uncovered critical insights into how added nutrients affect the structure, function, and sustainability of these ecosystems.

While earlier studies suggested that coastal marsh plants could absorb large amounts of nitrogen without harm, TIDE has shown that long-term nutrient enrichment, especially nitrate from upland runoff, can have serious consequences for marsh ecosystems. These include saltmarsh loss and changes to marsh geomorphology that ripple through the ecosystem, affecting nutrient cycling and fisheries.

Nutrients were added to the flooding waters of three tidal creeks at 15x reference levels, and a key predator in this system, the killifish (Fundulus heteroclitus), was also removed in some years to examine how food-web alterations impact trophic interactions and ecosystem functioning of the marsh. In 2017, the project stopped adding nutrients to study plots to assess how the ecosystems would recover.

Because the TIDE Project manipulations occur at such large spatial and temporal scales, these manipulations influence multiple components within the ecosystem - similar to how real-world impacts influence ecosystems. The project uses an interdisciplinary approach and observes a range of responses - from bacteria to birds, to biogeochemistry and geomorphology - for a more holistic understanding of salt marsh responses to perturbations.

The experiment revealed that increased nutrients shift plant growth, favoring aboveground biomass over the belowground roots that stabilize marshes. This shift weakens the marsh's structural integrity. At the same time, the added nutrients boost microbial decomposition contributing to less cohesive sediments. Together, these changes lead to erosion along marsh creek edges, altered marsh landscapes and foodwebs, reduced fish populations, and diminished carbon storage capacity.

The team also learned that after halting the addition of nutrients to the ecosystem that some parts of the ecosystem, such as plants and microbes, were able to quickly bounce back within a few years and restore carbon accumulation. However,  geomorphology, food webs and fish production are taking much longer to recover.  

The project has reached thousands of people with its findings, from the scientific community to the general public. More than 66 scientific articles have been published on the project’s research, including a landmark publication in Nature. That article upended the way people thought about the effects of eutrophication on marshes, and led to extensive media coverage  from The Boston Globe to NPR’s Morning Edition.

Over 200 people have participated in the TIDE Project since 2003, and more than 70 of those were young scientists, ranging from high school interns to post-doctoral scientists from multiple institutions and disciplines. Many undergraduates and post-bachelor’s students have been co-authors on TIDE-publications, and written reflections for the TIDE blog. They were critical in providing new concepts, and in working on the front lines of sampling and maintaining a large and challenging experiment.

Coastal areas worldwide face challenges from nutrient runoff into wetlands. Protecting and restoring these vital ecosystems, especially salt marshes, requires a clear understanding of how chronic nutrient loading and changes in species composition affect them. For over 20 years, the TIDE Project has been providing essential, science-backed insights into how moderate, sustained nutrient enrichment impacts coastal wetlands' productivity, food webs, and physical structure. This information is critical for crafting effective conservation strategies both nationally and globally.
